title: 5 stunning images of our solar system captured by NASA Hubble Space Telescope - HT Tech
summary:
5 Stunning Images of Our Solar System Captured by NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: December 16, 2024 | Source: HT TECH

This article showcases five stunning images of the solar system captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, highlighting the beauty and complexity of our cosmic neighborhood.

  • The solar system is approximately 4.5 billion years old.
  • Only two NASA spacecraft have exited our solar system.
  • About 500,000 pieces of space junk are currently orbiting Earth.
  • The Hubble Telescope captured a more powerful image of Mars in 2018 than previous spacecraft.
  • Images also include alien aurorae on Uranus and northern auroras on Saturn.
  • New insights into Jupiter's atmosphere have been gained through Hubble’s imagery.
“Hubble’s near-infrared imaging showcased the rainbow view of Jupiter, providing astronomers with an understanding of the planet’s atmosphere.”

The stunning images not only demonstrate the capabilities of modern telescopes but also inspire curiosity and wonder about the universe we inhabit.
newTitle: 5 Stunning Images of Our Solar System Captured by NASA Hubble Space Telescope

title: Superflares erupt from stars like our Sun once every 100 years - Deccan Herald
summary:
Superflares Erupt from Stars Like Our Sun Once Every 100 Years

Published: 16 December 2024, Source: Science

Our sun is a violent place, but scientists have observed even larger explosions from other stars, called superflares, which occur much more frequently than anticipated.

  • Superflares are explosions with the power of a trillion hydrogen bombs.
  • Stars similar to our sun generate superflares approximately once every century.
  • A recent study re-evaluated superflare data using advanced methodologies and found the occurrence rate to be higher than previous estimates.
  • The research team analyzed data from NASA's retired Kepler space telescope to identify sun-like stars.
  • Only about 1 in 20 sun-like stars were found to produce superflares.
“A solar superflare is something that society needs to worry about,” said Hugh Hudson, an astronomer, emphasizing the potential risks involved.

Understanding the frequency and implications of these events is crucial for preparing society for possible threats from solar activity.
newTitle: Superflares Erupt from Stars Like Our Sun Once Every 100 Years

6 Mesmerising Images Of Stars Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
summary:
6 Mesmerising Images Of Stars Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: Dec 16, 2024 Source: Times Now

This article showcases six stunning images of stars captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, revealing the beauty and complexity of the universe.

  • ESO 245-5: A crowded star field showing a large part of a galaxy, located 15 million light-years away.
  • Star AU Microscopii: Featuring a young planet and its dynamic relationship with a red dwarf star.
  • Stellar Cradle: Showcases the protostellar object OH 339.88-1.26, filled with dusty lanes and bright stars.
  • NGC 346: Depicts an active area of star formation within the Small Magellanic Cloud.
  • Stargazing In NGC 6355: Illustrates the globular cluster located within our Milky Way galaxy.
“Scientists were surprised to observe young stars spiraling towards the core of a large star cluster within the Small Magellanic Cloud.”

This remarkable collection of images highlights the wonders of astronomy and encourages further exploration of the cosmos.

title: Hubble took the closest-ever image of a quasar, and captured some 'weird things' - Earth.com
summary:
Hubble Captures Closest Image of Quasar 3C 273, Reveals Unique Structures

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Earth.com

Astronomers using NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope have explored the surrounding environment of quasar 3C 273 in unprecedented detail, revealing new features that may enhance our understanding of these powerful celestial objects.

  • Quasars are extremely luminous astronomical entities, powered by supermassive black holes.
  • The latest observations highlighted “weird things” in the quasar’s vicinity, including blobs and a mysterious L-shaped filament.
  • Quasar 3C 273 is the closest known quasar, located 2.5 billion light-years from Earth, emitting more energy than the brightest elliptical galaxies.
  • Hubble’s advanced instruments allowed researchers to examine fine details of the quasar’s host galaxy, unveiling dusty disks and intricate interactions.
  • The recent study sets the stage for future observations with the James Webb Space Telescope.
“Thanks to Hubble’s observing power, we’re opening a new gateway into understanding quasars.” - Bin Ren

The insights gained from observing quasar 3C 273 enhance our understanding of the cosmic processes that shape galaxies and quasars throughout the universe.
newTitle: Hubble Captures Closest Image of Quasar 3C 273, Reveals Unique Structures

title: Can we make black holes reveal themselves in echoes of light? - The Hindu
summary:
Can we make black holes reveal themselves in echoes of light?

Published: December 16, 2024 05:30 am IST Source: The Hindu

This article examines recent research on light echoes around black holes, highlighting a new method for measuring their properties through effects on light, as reported by a Princeton University study.

  • The study proposes using light echoes as a new way to measure black hole masses and spins.
  • Light passing around black holes bends and can create multiple light paths, leading to echoes.
  • The research employs a technique called long-baseline interferometry to detect these echoes.
  • The study focuses on black holes in the Milky Way and M87 galaxies.
  • Preliminary simulations support the technique and align with Einstein's theory of relativity.
Albert Einstein's general theory of relativity predicted that light echoes would occur, implying that they should be observable across different frequencies.

The findings offer intriguing insights into black holes and could significantly enhance our understanding of their characteristics and behavior in the universe.
newTitle: Can Light Echoes Help Us Understand Black Holes?

title: A new study warns about frequent solar superflares - The Times of India
Europe Launches Mission to Create Simulated Solar Eclipse - VOA Learning English
summary:
Europe Launches Mission to Create Simulated Solar Eclipse

Publication Date: December 5, 2023 | Source: VOA Learning English

Two European satellites were launched on a mission to simulate total solar eclipses, aiming to enhance our understanding of solar activity and the sun's corona.

  • Launched by the European Space Agency (ESA) from southern India.
  • The Proba-3 mission will test precision formation flying with satellites operating 150 meters apart.
  • Planned artificial eclipses will allow for detailed observation of the sun without its overwhelming brightness.
  • Each eclipse can last up to six hours, compared to the few minutes of natural eclipses.
  • The project aims to gather 1,000 hours of totality over its two-year mission.
“For six hours at a time, it will be able to see the sun's faint atmosphere, the corona...,” ESA stated.

This mission represents a significant step in solar research and is supported by over 40 European companies.
newTitle: Europe Launches Mission to Create Simulated Solar Eclipse

Rare gamma-ray flare unleashed from a supermassive black hole - Earth.com
summary:
Rare Gamma-Ray Flare Emanates from Supermassive Black Hole in M87

Date: Published in 2024, Source: Astronomy and Astrophysics

This article discusses a rare gamma-ray flare detected from the supermassive black hole at the heart of the galaxy M87, offering new insights into the physical mechanisms of particle acceleration near black holes.

  • The flare was emitted from the black hole in 2018 and lasted approximately three days.
  • It marked the first gamma-ray flaring event observed from this source in over a decade.
  • The flare's photons reached energy levels of several teraelectronvolts (TeV).
  • The emission region was estimated to be about ten times the size of the black hole.
  • The findings were part of an international observational campaign involving over 25 telescopes.
“We were lucky to detect a gamma-ray flare from M87 during this Event Horizon Telescope’s multi-wavelength campaign.” - Giacomo Principe

This discovery underscores the significance of collaborative research in astrophysics and opens avenues for further studies on supermassive black holes.
newTitle: Rare Gamma-Ray Flare Emanates from Supermassive Black Hole in M87

title: Mysterious 'Alien-Like' Creature Discovered By Scientists In Deep Ocean, Revealing Unexplored Marine World - Jagran English
summary:
Mysterious 'Alien-Like' Creature Discovered By Scientists In Deep Ocean, Revealing Unexplored Marine Worlds

Publication Date: December 11, 2024 | Source: RealClearScience

The deep sea remains one of the most mysterious and least understood areas of our planet. Recently, scientists discovered a new species of amphipod named Dulcibella camanchaca in the Atacama Trench, likened to alien-like creatures due to its unique appearance.

  • The discovery was made during a 2023 research expedition by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and Universidad de Concepción.
  • The Atacama Trench is known for harsh conditions, including high pressure and low light.
  • The name 'camanchaca' means 'darkness' in an Andean language, reflecting its deep-sea habitat.
  • The creature exhibits features that make it comparable to alien species, with a translucent body and elongated limbs.
  • This discovery emphasizes the unexplored diversity of life in ocean depths.
Dulcibella camanchaca: "A bizarre new predator has been discovered lurking 26,000 feet below the ocean's surface and has been named after its pitch-black home." — RealClearScience (@RCScience) December 11, 2024

As scientists continue to study Dulcibella camanchaca, they aim to uncover further insights into life in the ocean’s depths.
newTitle: Mysterious 'Alien-Like' Creature Discovered By Scientists In Deep Ocean, Revealing Unexplored Marine Worlds

summary:
See the best Geminid meteor shower 2024 photos from around the world

Publication Date: December 14, 2024 Source: Space.com

The Geminid meteor shower dazzled skywatchers this week with stunning displays captured across the globe, even under the challenge of a full moon.

  • The Geminids are known for their bright meteors and high hourly rates.
  • Photographer Osama Fathi captured impressive images of the shower from Egypt's Black Desert.
  • In Hawaii, the Subaru Telescope recorded over 150 meteors in one hour despite bright moonlight.
  • Amateur astronomers shared their best captures from various locations including Canada and Japan, showcasing the meteors along with notable celestial objects.
  • Various photographers documented unique phenomena during the shower, including multiple meteors appearing simultaneously.
"Despite the meteor shower coinciding with a full moon this year, I managed to capture this image before its peak, successfully recording several meteors despite the presence of some light clouds that added an artistic touch to the light." - Osama Fathi

The Geminid meteor shower continues to be a highlight for astronomers and astronomy enthusiasts alike, proving that even challenging conditions can yield breathtaking celestial displays.

title: Subabul seeds and insulin resistance management - BusinessLine
summary:
Subabul Seeds and Insulin Resistance Management

Updated - December 15, 2024 at The Hindu Business Line

Researchers at the Institute of Advanced Study in Science and Technology have explored the potential of Subabul seeds in managing insulin resistance associated with type II diabetes, leading to the development of four active bio-compounds.

  • Subabul, also known as Leucaena leucocephala, is a fast-growing tree found in tropical regions.
  • The leaves and seeds are nutritious and consumed in various forms.
  • Scientists developed a marker-assisted fraction to analyze the seeds' therapeutic properties.
  • The study underscores the importance of traditional plants in modern medicinal research.
“The therapeutic potential of Subabul highlights its importance in managing diabetes.”

This research opens new avenues for utilizing traditional plants in managing metabolic disorders.
newTitle: Subabul Seeds: A Natural Approach to Managing Insulin Resistance

James Webb telescope spots more than 100 new asteroids between Jupiter and Mars — and some are heading toward Earth - Livescience.com
summary:
James Webb Telescope Discovers Over 100 New Asteroids Near Earth

Publication Date: December 9, 2024 Source: Live Science

Astronomers utilizing the James Webb Space Telescope have made a groundbreaking discovery of over 100 previously unknown asteroids in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. Some of these tiny asteroids are on trajectories that may bring them near Earth, enhancing our capabilities for tracking potential hazards.

  • The asteroids found range in size from that of a bus to several stadiums.
  • These small asteroids collide with Earth significantly more frequently than larger ones, yet are harder to detect.
  • Researchers employed advanced methods to analyze JWST images, leading to the discovery of 138 new asteroids, six of which are projected to approach Earth.
  • This discovery signifies a new era in asteroid detection, utilizing infrared technology to uncover these elusive objects.
"We thought we would just detect a few new objects, but we detected so many more than expected — especially small ones," said Julien de Wit.

This discovery opens new avenues for planetary defense and increases our understanding of asteroid dynamics in the solar system.
newTitle: James Webb Telescope Discovers Over 100 New Asteroids Near Earth

NASA’s Juno probe reveals factors driving excessive volcanism on Io - News9 LIVE
summary:
NASA’s Juno probe reveals factors driving excessive volcanism on Io

Publication Date: New Delhi,
Source: Science News

Io is a moon of Jupiter with an estimated 400 volcanoes that continuously erupt, covering its surface in volcanic material. Observations from NASA's Juno probe suggest that each volcano is powered by its own magma chamber, rather than a shared subsurface magma ocean. This discovery helps to clarify the origins of Io's volcanic activity, a question that has puzzled scientists since the Voyager I mission in 1979.

  • Io is the most volcanic body in the Solar System, featuring around 400 volcanoes.
  • The research indicates that volcanoes on Io are powered by separate magma chambers.
  • This finding challenges previous assumptions of a global ocean of magma beneath Io's surface.
  • The data was collected during close flybys of Io in 2023 and 2024 by the Juno spacecraft.
“Since Morabito’s discovery, planetary scientists have wondered how the volcanoes were fed from the lava underneath the surface.” - Scott Bolton

This research provides vital insights into the geological activities of Io and will likely influence future explorations and studies of volcanic bodies in our Solar System.
newTitle: NASA’s Juno Probe Uncovers Secrets of Volcanism on Jupiter's Moon Io

title: 7 captivating images of star clusters shared by NASA - India.com
summary:
7 Captivating Images of Star Clusters Shared by NASA

Publication Date: December 15, 2024 Source: India.com

This article showcases a collection of breathtaking images of star clusters captured by NASA, highlighting their beauty and astronomical significance.

  • The globular cluster located in the Large Magellanic Cloud is about 100 million years old and lies approximately 160,000 light-years from Earth.
  • A few young stars can be seen shining through dense clouds of gas and dust in the Orion Nebula's Trapezium cluster.
  • NGC 2660, visually striking, can be best seen in the southern sky.
  • NGC 1858 is a 10-million-year-old open star cluster in the Large Magellanic Cloud, rich with star-forming regions.
  • NGC 2002 is an open star cluster located roughly 160,000 light-years away in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
  • Images also include Caldwell 71, a loose collection of relatively young stars, and the globular cluster NGC 2031 located in the constellation Mensa.
“Thanks For Reading!”

This article emphasizes the wonders of cosmic beauty and NASA's role in documenting it, inspiring readers to appreciate the universe.
newTitle: 7 Captivating Images of Star Clusters Shared by NASA
